terms.definition: A specific financial target you aim to achieve within a set timeframe. Financial goals provide direction for your saving, spending, and investing decisions.
A framework for creating effective goals: Specific, Measurable, Achievable, Relevant, Time-bound‚Äîa proven structure for goal success.
terms.example: Each component ensures your goal is clear and actionable

terms.definition: A financial objective to be achieved within one year. Quick wins that build momentum and develop your goal-setting skills.
terms.example: Emergency fund, new phone, concert tickets, paying off small debt

terms.definition: A financial objective that takes more than one year to achieve. Requires patience and strategic planning but yields greater rewards.
terms.example: College savings, buying a car, investment portfolio, travel fund

scenario.name: Riley's Success with SMART Goals
paragraphs: Riley wants to buy an $800 laptop for college in 8 months. Using the SMART framework, Riley creates a specific plan: save $100 each month through automatic transfers to a dedicated savings account and track progress using a savings app.
Riley makes the goal achievable by identifying specific adjustments: reducing eating out by $50 monthly and earning another $50 through a part-time job. Strategic planning leads to achievement.

scenario.name: Morgan's Struggles with Vague Goals
paragraphs: Morgan wants to "save some money for the future." Without specific amounts or deadlines, Morgan doesn't feel any urgency to save consistently. Some months, Morgan puts away $50; other months, nothing at all.
Morgan doesn't track progress or have a clear target to work toward. After a year, Morgan has saved only $275 sporadically and feels discouraged about financial planning.

main.title: Create Your SMART Goals
main.description: Practice turning financial aspirations into actionable, achievable goals using the SMART framework for both short-term and long-term objectives. Materials: SMART Goals Worksheet, calculator, savings app (optional).

steps: Choose one short-term goal (within 1 year) and one long-term goal (more than 1 year)
Apply each SMART criterion to both goals: Specific, Measurable, Achievable, Relevant, Time-bound
Write your complete SMART goal statement in one clear sentence for each
Identify potential obstacles and strategies to overcome them
Plan specific actions you'll take in the next week to begin working toward each goal

content.tagline: Set Goals. Take Action. Build Your Future.
